title: 110_hr4049
content: The "Money Service Business Act of 2008" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The Congress acknowledges that money services businesses provide essential financial services to a diverse customer base, including under-banked communities. These services encompass various transactions such as funds transfers, check cashing, and electronic bill payments. Regulatory guidance requires depository institutions to monitor money services businesses' anti-money laundering compliance programs. The trend of insured depository institutions refusing or closing money services businesses' accounts threatens the legitimate industry and national security by driving transactions underground. Money services businesses must maintain transparency in transactions to comply with anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing obligations enforced by State and Federal regulators. Regulators are authorized to oversee compliance and impose sanctions on these businesses. Coordination between State and Federal regulators is crucial for effective supervision and enforcement. Insured depository institutions and Federal banking regulators rely on a regulatory process for overseeing money services businesses' compliance with anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing obligations. Self-certification by legitimate businesses is also important to reduce regulatory burden and promote access to the banking system. Federal and State agencies have authority to supervise and enforce compliance with these obligations. To reduce regulatory burden and promote access to the banking system, self-certification processes are necessary under the Act and its implementing regulations. Self-certification process for money services businesses established. The self-certification process for money services businesses is established under Section 5318(h) of title 31, United States Code. A federally insured depository institution maintaining an account for a money transmitting business is not obligated to review the compliance of the business or its agents if a certification meeting specific requirements is on file. The self-certification process for money services businesses under Section 5318(h) of title 31, United States Code requires a certification from the business that the named agent is authorized to act as the principal's agent. Civil penalties apply for making a material misrepresentation in the certification. The self-certification process for money services businesses under Section 5318(h) of title 31, United States Code requires a certification from the business that the named agent is authorized to act as the principal's agent. Criminal penalties apply for knowingly making a material misrepresentation in the certification, regardless of whether the violation was willful. Additionally, federally insured depository institutions are not required to manage accounts for money transmitting businesses or their agents. A federally insured depository institution is not liable for a money transmitting business or its agent failing to comply with regulations. The term 'federally insured depository institution' includes insured depository institutions and insured credit unions. Money transmitting businesses must provide a certification to meet requirements. Money transmitting businesses must certify compliance with regulations, maintain an anti-money laundering program, and be licensed. The business must be licensed or registered as a money transmitting business by each State where it operates, registered with the Secretary in accordance with section 5330, and remain in compliance with regulations. The agent of a money transmitting business must certify certain requirements to the Secretary, including being an agent of a business meeting specific criteria, appearing on the business's list of agents, and operating under a written contract. The agent of a money transmitting business must certify in writing that they will act honestly, comply with laws, and promptly inform any bank of any significant changes in their relationship with the business. The agent of a money transmitting business must certify in writing that they will act honestly, comply with laws, and promptly inform any bank of any significant changes in their relationship with the business. The agent must also be licensed or registered as a money transmitting business by the State in which they operate, and they are not required to be registered with the Secretary as a money transmitting business. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue regulations to implement the amendments within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on July 22, 2008. Clerk: LORRAINE C. MILLER.
